sections.title: Start With Internal Capital
sections.content: Bootstrapping through savings, customer pre-orders, and revenue reinvestment keeps ownership intact. Track burn rate weekly and delay outside funding until you prove repeatable demand.

points.title: Debt Financing
points.description: Best for stable cash flow and asset-heavy businesses. Protect your credit score and collateral requirements.

points.title: Equity
points.description: Angel and VC money accelerates growth but dilutes ownership—come prepared with traction and a scalable model.

points.title: Non-Dilutive
points.description: Revenue-based financing, grants, and competitions offer capital without ownership loss but require clear payback triggers.

sections.title: Know Your Runway
sections.content: Runway = current cash ÷ monthly burn. Aim for at least 12 months before raising so you negotiate from strength.

sections.title: Capital Planning Checklist
steps: Calculate your burn rate and runway for the next 12 months.
List three funding sources that align with your stage and risk tolerance.
Prepare a one-page investor brief including traction, margins, and use of funds.
Identify required legal documents (cap table, financial statements, IP assignments).
Schedule outreach to at least five potential funding partners and document responses.

sections.title: Stack Your Capital
sections.content: Mix smaller capital sources—grants, founder loans, strategic partners—to diversify risk and extend runway before major rounds.
